Word: anḍ- "to be hungry or thirsty, (food or drink) is wanting, (hunger or thirst) is felt"
Additional forms: Also Parjianḍkuḍthirst
Notes: ! Irregular case.

Additional forms: Also Parjiaḍḍom er-to obstruct
Notes: The final-min these forms may betray their origin as borrowings from Telugu (although this is not certain).
A very rare case of such a cluster in PKG, resulting in a unique occurrence of-yb-in Parji.

Additional forms: Also Parjimāva aṭṭ-to harrow;poṭkul aṭṭ-to clap hands, snap fingers
Also Naikriayka(pl.-śikuḷ) husband's elder sister; Parjiiya(pl.iyov) mother; Ollariayalwoman, wife;asmalwoman; Salurayālwife;āsmalwoman

Word: ōd (obl. ōn-), ōr, ad, av "that man, those men, that woman or thing, those women or things"
Additional forms: Also Kolami adj. (rarely used)ā; Naikri adj.ā; Parji adj.ā; Ollari adj.ā,āy
Notes: The inflected forms are as follows:*avnd_(masc. sg.),*avr(masc. pl.),*ad(fem. sg.). As for the fem./neut. pl. form, external data shows*avto be most archaic. The formadavhas obviously developed by analogy withad; as for Naikianda, it is unclear.

Word: alc- "to wind round (as snake or creeper round tree)"
Additional forms: Also Parjialṭ-to be twined around;alṭayp-(alṭayt-) to wind round (tr.)
Notes: In DEDR Salurall-is separately placed in entry 260 as 'to twine' and entry 207 as 'to spread as a creeper'.

Additional forms: Also Kolamialp-(alapt-) to make to become tired

Word: ale "exclamation used as voc. (a formalorwith the termination of the 2nd pl. is also recorded)"
anḍ- "(S) to attach string to bow"

Additional forms: Also Saluranuyk-to kill, destroy
Notes: Initialn-in South Parji is unclear; quite obviously, it cannot be of archaic origin.

Additional forms: Also Kolamiaṭip-(aṭipt-) to stick (tr.), put (child) to breast; Naikriaṭip-to stick (tr.)

Word: aŋalp- (aŋalt-) "to gape, open the mouth wide"
Notes: The Parji form goes back to*aŋ-l-(in PGn this is the regular form for this root).

Additional forms: Also Kolamiayak(obl.ayk-) rubbish
Also Parjiaṭuattic room.
Notes: Parjiaṭuis almost certainly a cultural borrowing from Telugu;aṭṭa, however, may be original.

Word: aṛj- "(flavor of something) is perceived (particularly salt,cup aṛjoto)"
Additional forms: Also Parjiaṛcip-(aṛcit-) to add as flavouring

Notes: Ollariarg-<*ār-g-.

Notes: External data shows*-v-to be original. Both variants were probably free, with*-v->*-m-due to expressive character of the form.

Word: ēk- "to pick and throw away stones and weeds from field"

Word: kañcip- (kañcit-) "(S) to fasten bullock to yoke"

Additional forms: Also Kolamikeḍkhard
Notes: Contamination is certain here, although the exact meanings of both roots is hard to determine. While  on first sight it would be natural to assume the meaning 'spleen' for*kaṭ-and 'hard' for*gaṭ-, this hardly seems convenient considering that in some SDR and Gondwan languages it is just the opposite. There's also a possibility of devoicing in Naikri through assimilation.

Additional forms: Also Parjikaṛpathin stick, twig, beanstick; Salur (P)kanvestick;kanḍven(pl.kanḍvēl) id.
